title: Haunting CCTV shows moment trucker pulls into Essex industrial estate
text:
This is the dramatic moment a CCTV camera filmed a lorry pulling into an industrial estate where it was found just half an hour later with 39 dead bodies inside.

Footage shows the lorry at 01.10am this morning driving along the road next to Waterglade Industrial Park in Grays, Essex, where it was found 30 minutes later.

Mo Robinson, 25, of Portadown, Northern Ireland, the driver of the red and white Scovia lorry, was arrested on suspicion of murder this morning at 1.40am.

The CCTV shows the lorry traveling along the small road in the dark with the lights switched on, and the trucker cannot be seen behind the wheel of the left hand drive.

Police said the trailer travelled from Zeebrugge into Purfleet, and docked in the Thurrock area. The tractor unit is believed to have originated in Northern Ireland.

Detetctives originally reported that the lorry had travelled into the country through Holyhead on October 19, but they now believe the trailer travelled from Belgium.

The driver remained in custody tonight, while a cordon remained in place in the area around the estate. Police said it would be a 'lengthy and complex investigation'.

Mr Robinson is believed to have driven from his home in a small village in Portadown over the weekend and collected the trailer from the port of Purfleet late last night.

His lorry was later seen driving into the Waterglade estate, where ambulance crews and police attended and found 39 people dead in the back, including a teenager.

The trailer was delivered to Purfleet by ship from Zeebrugge at around midnight last night. The origin of the container before it got to Zeebrugge is not known.

Mr Robinson regularly posts about the Bulgarian-registered Scania truck on his social media pages, referring to it as 'the Scandinavian Express' and 'the Polar Express'.

Police at the Waterglade Industrial Park in Grays today after 39 bodies were found in a lorry

The lorry was reportedly registered in Bulgaria by an Irish company in 2017, then driven out of the eastern-European country to Northern Ireland.

The lorry's trailer is understood to be refrigerated, meaning temperatures inside could have been as low as -25C.

Prime Minister Boris Johnson has said he is 'appalled' by the tragedy and that his thoughts are with those who lost their lives and their loved ones.

It is the biggest disaster of its kind since 2000, when 58 Chinese stowaways died on a ferry from Belgium to Britain.
